analytic.title: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Coral bleaching, Global climate change, Photosynthesis, Non-photochemical quenching, Symbiosis, Symbiodinium Abbreviations Chlorophyll, Chl
F B , stress conditions equivalent to coral bleaching conditions
F HL , high light stress condition
F HT , elevated temperature stress conditions
FWHM, full width at half maximum

abstract.p: The global rise in sea surface temperatures causes regular exposure of corals to high temperature and high light stress, leading to worldwide disastrous coral bleaching events (loss of symbiotic dinoflagellates (Symbiodinium) from reef-building corals). Our picosecond chlorophyll fluorescence experiments on cultured Symbiodinium Clade C cells exposed to coral bleaching conditions uncovered the transformations of the alga's photosynthetic apparatus (PSA) that activate an extremely efficient non-photochemical "super-quenching" mechanism. The mechanism is associated with a transition from an initially heterogeneous photosystem II (PSII) pool to a homogeneous "spillover" pool, where nearly all excitation energy is transferred to photosystem I (PSI). There, the inherently higher stability of PSI and high quenching efficiency of P 700 + allow dumping of PSII excess excitation energy into heat, resulting in almost complete cessation of photosynthetic electron transport (PET). This potentially reversible "superquenching" mechanism protects the PSA against destruction at the cost of a loss of photosynthetic activity. We suggest that the inhibition of PET and the consequent inhibition of organic carbon production (e.g. sugars) in the symbiotic Symbiodinium provide a trigger for the symbiont expulsion, i.e. bleaching.

div.head: A C C E P T E D
div.p: M A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Coral reefs provide the scaffolding and the habitat for some of the largest and most diverse ecosystems on the planet. Corals consist of a complex and fragile symbiosis between an animal host (phylum Cnidaria) and endosymbiotic microalgae (dinoflagellates from the genus Symbiodinium). Dinoflagellate photopigments (chlorophylls (Chl) a, c 2; and carotenoids) give the coral an overall brown coloration, but a range of host pigments combine to produce the colorful array of species we see across a coral reef. Prolonged exposure of corals to high irradiance and an elevated seawater temperature, ~1-2ºC above the summer average, induces pigment degradation and/or triggers the release of the Symbiodinium photosymbiont from the host [1], which in turn causes uncovering of the white skeleton underlying the animal tissue (coral bleaching). The bleaching phenomenon is often followed by death of the coral [1,2]. In this respect, the health of the coral holobiont is critical for the survival of corals and therefore of coral reefs and their denizens. However, global climate changes (especially the rising ocean temperature and ocean acidification) are threatening the health of this symbiotic relationship worldwide [2][3][4]. Current predictions indicate that coral reefs may face extinction by 2050 [3,4].

Therefore, it is critical to understand the fundamental processes in the algal-host association, especially the photosynthetic processes of the algae, which appear to be a crucial trigger point of coral bleaching [5,6].

The general consensus is that mass coral bleaching is due to the dysfunction of photosynthetic processes (such as pronounced reduction in the activity of photosystem (PS) II and in linear electron transport) in the algal symbiont as a result of the combined action of elevated temperature and light-stress [7]. This initial impact is followed by activation of the Mehler Ascorbate Peroxidase (MAP) pathway, which at low stress levels may have a protective effect [8]. However, at high stress levels it is likely that generation of reactive oxygen species in this pathway will actually stimulate bleaching [9].

Over the last decade, a variety of Symbiodinium clades with differing photosynthetic properties and tolerances to elevated water temperatures have been studied [2,10,11]. However, scarce knowledge on the ultrastructure and the light-dependent reaction of the photosynthetic apparatus (PSA) in dinoflagellates has hindered the understanding of coral bleaching. It is known that the structure of the thylakoid membrane, that houses the light reactions, differs substantially from

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: that in higher plants [12]. In higher plants, the thylakoid membranes form tightly appressed, stacked regions (grana) connected by single stroma thylakoids, due to the inter-membrane interaction of the PSII peripheral light-harvesting complexes (LHCs). This thylakoid ultrastructure enforces strict lateral separation of PSII and PSI between the grana and the stroma membrane regions respectively, which does not allow for intersystem excitation energy transfer (known as "spillover" in the literature) [13]. In contrast, the thylakoids of dinoflagellates, as in many microalgae [14], are loosely grouped in threes which allows mixing of PSII and PSI units and thus spillover.

High levels of irradiance exceeding the utilisation capacity of the PSA can be damaging for the photosynthetic complexes. In this respect, photosynthetic organisms have developed an adaptive feature, known as non-photochemical quenching (NPQ), where excess harvested light energy is converted into heat [15]. Many studies have demonstrated that symbiotic algae in corals have similarly developed adaptive processes to cope with conditions of high solar irradiation [2,16] to protect the photosystems [17] and ultimately the whole cell against oxidative damage [7].
However, the details of NPQ and the mechanisms of redistribution of excitation energy operating in dinoflagellates and especially in Symbiodinium sp. are largely unknown.

Ultrafast time-resolved Chl fluorescence, in combination with kinetic modeling [18], has contributed significantly to our understanding of the light harvesting processes and their regulation in photosynthetic organisms. The combination of these two methods has provided a tool which gives much greater detail and much better reliability on the location and mechanisms of the photoprotection in the antennae than was possible with the widely used steady-state Chl fluorescence methods. This non-invasive approach has also been successfully applied to study NPQ in diatom algae [19] and lichens [20], but not yet in dinoflagellates.

We have employed the above-mentioned approach to characterize the largely unknown structural and functional changes that occur in the PSA of coral symbionts exposed to stress conditions relevant to coral bleaching. Our studies on the temperature induced transformation of cultured Symbiodinium cells from unstressed to photoprotective mode of operation reveal the molecular origins of a "super-quenching" state that plays a central role in both photoprotection and coral bleaching.
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 6

div.head: Materials and methods
Sample preparation
div.p: The fluorometer (Walz, Effeltrich, Germany) showed that the ultrasound had no effect on the physiological state of the algae.

div.head: Time-correlated single photon counting fluorescence set-up
div.p: Time-resolved fluorescence measurements were performed to examine the changes in the functional state of the Symbiodinium cells and relate these to structural changes in the PSA. The single-photon timing technique was used to record the picosecond fluorescence decays at 10 different wavelengths in the range 670-750 nm. The set-up consisted of a synchronouslypumped, cavity-dumped, mode-locked dye laser operating at 800 kHz or 4 MHz repetition frequency [22]. The pulse of the dye laser has a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of ~10 ps and the whole response of the system is ~30 ps FWHM, which after deconvolution results in a time resolution of ~2 ps. The laser intensity at the sample was <0.5 mW, ~0.8 mm spot diameter.

The excitation wavelength to selectively excite the bulk antenna Chls was 662 nm. A flowthrough cuvette system, as designed previously [19], was used for the measurements (Supporting information (SI), Fig. S4).

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Measures for achieving homogeneous PSII redox state during the measurement
div.p: The control sample and the other measurement conditions were carefully designed to ensure that the kinetics under the various treatments could be easily compared. Different light and temperature conditions in the pretreatments would naturally lead to a heterogeneity in the redox state of the PSII RCs, which would complicate the analysis of the time-resolved fluorescence data or even make a meaningful kinetic modeling impossible [19]. We have thus chosen the measuring conditions to ensure that in all cases all of the PSII RCs were in a closed state at the time of the measurement (i.e. when the measured sample volume passes the measuring laser beam in the flow-through cuvette). Such a homogeneous state is easily achieved either by DCMU incubation (in the case of unquenched dark adapted samples) or by short additional illumination (~200 ms duration of 3000 µmol photons m -2 s -1 ) applied by a high intensity LED right before the sample volume enters the measuring laser spot.

div.head: Experimental pretreatments and measurement conditions
div.p: The experimental treatments applied to the cultured Symbiodinium were designed to compare optimal growth conditions and conditions known to cause coral bleaching [23]. Four different treatments (incubation and measurement periods) were applied to the samples ( All incubation periods before the measurements were 10 h to ensure the algae were brought to a steady state (tested by fluorescence induction) characteristic for a particular environmental condition. The shift from 24°C to 31°C was thus ramped gradually (0.5°C/30 min). The illumination during the measurements was provided by royal blue LEDs (Luxeon Star/O LEDs, Philips Lumileds Lighting Company; maximum peak wavelength 450-455nm). The total duration of the fluorescence measurements at a particular experimental condition was 3 h. In the high-light adapted cases the PSII RCs were "closed" in the flow-through cuvette immediately before the sample volume flowed through the measuring laser beam by short additional illumination (~200 ms of strong additional illumination of 3000 µmol photons m -2 s -1 ).

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Data analysis
div.p: The fluorescence decays were analyzed by means of global and target analysis [24][25][26]. "Global" refers to simultaneous fitting of the decay curves at different wavelengths. In its basic form, global analysis is a pure mathematical fitting of the data with a "sum of exponentials function".

The analysis results in lifetimes and pre-exponential amplitudes, which yield the so-called decayassociated spectra (DAS). The DAS is a simple and compact way of representing the complete set of original data. In the more elaborate form, called "target" analysis several different detailed kinetic models are tested on the experimental data for exploring which of these models is consistent with and best describes the experimental data. Such an approach allows detailed information to be obtained about the rate constants of the fundamental processes of energy transfer and charge separation, as well as quenching, occurring in the particular system under investigation. This kind of analysis also resolves the spectra of the different compartments (species-associated emission spectra, SAES) represented in the kinetic model. The rate constants
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: along with the SAES are the main criteria by which the suitability of a kinetic model can be judged. The SAES should reflect the appropriate spectral features assigned to a particular compartment of the kinetic model, e.g. PSII or PSI properties, etc. [19,[27][28][29]. From the resulting rate constants and the SAES, the DAS can also be recalculated.

The kinetic modeling allows also the extraction of another valuable parameterthe so-called excitation vector. The excitation vector represents the relative initial excitation probabilities of the different model compartments. This excitation probability is directly related to total absorption cross-section of a particular compartment at the excitation wavelength, i.e. it is related to the number of pigments in a complex. In particular, for photosynthetic complexes, where the extinction coefficient of the studied pigments (here Chls and carotenoids) are very similar, the excitation probability provides information about the size of the antenna system of the model compartments (PSII or PSI). During the kinetic modeling we have tested a variety of different kinetic models for compatibility with the retrieved experimental data, taking into account previous knowledge about different structural and functional aspects of the studied samples [19,28].

div.head: Transmission electron microscopy
div.p: For transmission electron microscopy (TEM), cells were pre-incubated as described above examined with a Phillips CM12 transmission electron microscope. Images were taken with a CCD camera (Gatan). Measurements of the overall width of the bands of thylakoids were carried out using ImageJ on four independent micrographs each to account for slight differences in focal values. 5-10 measurements per micrograph were taken and data analyzed for statistical significance using the non-paired t-test.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Results
Transmission electron microscopy
div.p: Electron microscopy was employed to examine the status of the thylakoid membranes of Symbiodinium cells (strain CS-156, clade C) under normal and stressed conditions. distances became more irregular, with loss, especially, of the tight attachment between the stromal surfaces of the inner membranes (Fig. 2 C, G). In order to quantify the differences, the overall width of the bands of thylakoids (over six membranes) was measured. As shown in

div.head: Global lifetime analysis of the fluorescence data
div.p: The analysis of the time-resolved data indicated that in the control (F C ) measurement, the contribution of the long-lived states (originating from PSII) was dominant and thus long average fluorescence lifetimes of 500-700 ps (depending on the emission wavelength) were obtained (SI, Fig. S1). Please note that the F C condition corresponds to an F max condition where the RC are in closed state (see Materials and methods section), thus the long lifetime components are associated with PSII and are not due to detached antenna. High light stress (F HL ) caused shortening of the lifetime components (average lifetime ~200-300 ps) due to NPQ [19,28].
Under temperature stress conditions (F HT and bleaching F B ), the average lifetimes were further drastically shortened (to ~100 ps) due to the disappearance of all PSII lifetimes longer than 1 ns.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: In fact, the major lifetime amplitude in F B cells was now associated with a new, very short (3.5 ps) lifetime component (SI, Fig. S1). The shortening of the average lifetime indicated that the stress treatments opened additional excited state deactivation (quenching) pathways in the photosynthetic units (PSU) causing a reduction in the overall Chl fluorescence yield and lifetime, as shown in detail by the kinetic target modeling.

div.head: Kinetic target modeling of the fluorescence data
div.p: To reveal the detailed changes induced in the PSA by the various stress conditions, kinetic target modeling was performed. Initially, the usual kinetic scheme of unconnected PSII and PSI primary processes that were successful in describing the kinetics of both control and high light stressed higher plants [28] as well as diatoms [19] were tested (SI, Fig. S2A). However, such a kinetic scheme was grossly unsuitable to describe the data of Symbiodinium cells under any of the experimental conditions. All modifications of the unconnected PSII and PSI reaction schemes resulted in unsuccessful model fits. The kinetic schemes that successfully fit the data are summarized in Fig. 3. Consequently, connected schemes were tested by introducing a rate constant k so accounting for a process -traditionally called "spillover"by which PSII transfers excitation energy to PSI (SI, Fig. S2B). Since efficient excited state energy transfer occurs over relatively short distances (typically ≤ 20-30Å) [32], spillover from PSII to PSI is possible only if direct contact of the two antenna systems within the same membrane exists. Such a direct contact appears feasible in Symbiodinium due to the loose packing of the thylakoids (Fig. 2 and [14, 33]), which could strongly reduce PSII-PSI segregation as compared to higher plants. Introduction of spillover into the model did indeed allow for an excellent description of the high-temperature conditions with or without additional light stress (F B and F HT , correspondingly). However, the kinetic model was still not suitable for the description of the control (F C ) and high-light (F HL )

conditions. For the latter two cases, a scheme with a heterogeneous PSII population, one part involved in spillover to PSI, and the other part behaving "normally" (non-spillover PSII), was required (SI, Fig. S2C). Under optimal temperature conditions (F C and F HL ) both PSII populations were present; while under temperature stress conditions (F HT and F B ) the nonspillover population of PSII disappeared. The results are presented in Figs. 3 and 4 and Table 1 (details in SI, Figs. S2/S3 and Tables S1/S2). Note: a complete overview of the different modeling parameters, e.g. rate constants, weighted eigenvector matrices, etc. can be found in the SI (Tables S1 and S2). F C (control condition), F HL (high light stress), F HT (elevated temp. stress), F B (bleaching conditions).

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The use of kinetic models to fit the experimental data allows for extraction of the spectra of the different model compartments, specifically of PSII and PSI (see Materials and methods section).
Comparison with previous ultrafast time-resolve fluorescence studies on other oxygen-evolving photosynthetic organisms [19,28,34] and of isolated PSI and PSII particles [18,27,29,35],

shows that in the Symbiodinium cells studied here the intrinsic rate constants, resulting from the data fitting to the kinetic models, as well as the shapes and spectral positions SAES (Fig. 4A-C) are all within the range typical for PSI and PSII. The SAES of PSII peak at about ~680 nm, while the SAES of PSI are located at ~690 nm. The relative excitation probabilities (Table 1) The similar excitation probability of spillover and non-spillover PSII under control conditions (F C ), 0.26 and 0.21 respectively, indicated that the two PSII pools were similar in size (Table 1).

In addition, the antenna size of the complete PSII pool (PSII spillover and non-spillover) and PSI were also almost the same (total excitation probability ~0.5). The high light (F HL ) condition did not induce significant changes in the relative excitation probabilities of PSI and PSII, which indicated that photosystems were stable and that essentially no antenna movement from one photosystem to the other occurred. Fig. S3 for the equivalent spectra under the F HT condition). Note that the DAS presented here show higher complexity than the ones obtained from the simple global analysis (SI, Fig. S1). This is a consequence of the higher kinetic and component resolution inherently associated with the kinetic modeling. All the lifetimes in D-F can be traced back to the kinetic rate constants as provided in the SI (Table S2).

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Discussion
Effects of light stress
div.p: Our results ( Table 1, and Tables S1/S2 in the SI) show that under normal temperature conditions (F C and F HL ) two PSII populationsspillover and non-spillovercoexisted in the Symbiodinium cells in a ca. 60/40 ratio. The spillover rate was moderate (0.48 ns -1 ) under dark-adapted conditions and even decreased substantially under light-stress (0.13 ns -1 ) possibly due to lightinduced modifications of the peripheral PSII antenna. For both PSII populations, light-stress caused a strong increase in the direct antenna deactivation rate k NPQ (from a dark-adapted value of 0.35 ns -1 to 2.6 ns -1 and 1.5 ns -1 respectively, for spillover and non-spillover PSII units). The strong increase in k NPQ could be considered as the normal photoprotective PSII NPQ related to the light-induced xanthophyll cycle [19,28,36] which also occurs in Symbiodinium [37].
Evidently, this photoprotective effect was sufficient to avoid damage to PSII at the applied high light intensity since no significant population of photoinhibited PSII centers was observed.

Under the light-stress condition (F HL ), the spillover PSII component did show some enhanced far-red emission (Fig. 4B) that was reminiscent of the quenched peripheral LHCII fluorescence in higher plants [28]. This indicated that a similar quenching process was activated in
Symbiodinium, but without a pronounced antenna detachment (in agreement with [38,39]).

div.head: Temperature stress and bleaching conditions
div.p: The observed quenching effects were very different when temperature stress was applied either alone (F HT ) or in combination with light stress (F B ). The population of non-spillover PSII centers disappeared entirely and all PSII units turned into spillover centers (Fig. 3). Furthermore, the spillover rate increased strongly (up to 3 fold) as compared to non-heat-stressed conditions (Table 1). Additionally, the emergence of a minor free antenna component showed that part of the peripheral PSII antenna, that was initially associated with the non-spillover PSII units,

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: became functionally disconnected from the PSII core (contributing up to ~7-8% of the total absorption cross-section at the excitation wavelength), while another part connected to PSI. This explained the increase in the relative absorption cross-section of PSI in comparison to control temperature conditions (from ~50% to about ~65-70%, Table 1). These effects were obvious in F HT but became even more pronounced in F B . Our results are consistent with recent studies of Hoogenboom et al. [40] and Hill et al. [16], which also indicated the presence of a mobile LHC pool moving between PSII and PSI depending on temperature. Under temperature stress conditions the drastically reduced overall PSII average lifetimes are explained by two effects: i) the very high spillover rates from PSII to PSI; and, ii) the increased antenna deactivation rate, k NPQ . The former, however, clearly dominates the PSII deactivation under temperature stress.

The spillover is clearly a photoprotective mechanism since it diverts excess excitation energy away from PSII and towards PSI, where it is harmlessly converted to heat due to the high quenching efficiency of P 700 + [41,42]. Effectively, this protects the most vulnerable component of the PSA, PSII, in a similar manner as NPQ located in the PSII peripheral antenna.

div.head: Molecular model for thylakoid reorganization
div.p: Based on our results, we propose a structural/functional model for the heat stress-induced reorganization of the thylakoid membrane in Symbiodinium (Fig. 5). The TEM pictures (Fig. 2) obtained for high temperature incubations show a trend for loss of the typical thylakoid arrangement in dinoflagellates. Such an effect has been observed previously for longer heat stress exposures [30,31]. Unfortunately, very little is known about the arrangement of pigmentprotein complexes in the thylakoid membranes of dinoflagellates, thus no data exist about the PSI/PSII distribution along the thylakoid membranes. However, the arrangement of the photosynthetic complexes in the thylakoid membranes and their rearrangement induced by stress factors can be deduced by spectroscopic methods. Indeed, our fluorescence data (Figs. 3 and 4) show that under normal conditions (F C ), there exist two PSII pools: one involved in spillover to PSI (predominantly located in the non-appressed membrane regions) and another (predominantly located in the appressed regions and thus laterally segregated from PSI) that does not exchange excitation energy with PSI (Fig. 3A). Hence, the strict PSII-PSI segregation, typical for higher plant thylakoids, is not realized in Symbiodinium under non-stressed control conditions (F C ). The effect can be well understood considering the low degree of membrane appression in

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: dinoflagellate thylakoids [30,43], which allows mixing of PSII and PSI units in the nonappressed regions. There is also some (8%) dissociation of light harvesting antenna, previously attached to PSII.

Interestingly, our data did not reveal significant changes in this membrane organization induced by light stress only (F HL ). This is in agreement with the work of [39] where the 77 K fluorescence from Symbiodinium clade B and C exposed to similar light conditions did not show dissociation of the peripheral antenna from PSII. Initially, light-induced dissociation was proposed for clade A [39], which would suggest a photoprotective mechanism for this clade similar to the one proposed for diatoms and higher plants [19,28]. However, a different view has been put forward recently [38].

Under temperature stress (F HT and F B ), on the other hand, the lateral segregation of PSII and PSI in Symbiodinium, is lost entirely (Fig. 5B)only PSII involved in spillover is resolved in the analysis of the fluorescence kinetics. This is most likely related to major reorganization of the thylakoid membrane, associated with partial dissociation of the peripheral antenna complexes from the PSII supercomplex. This reorganizations can be linked to unfavorable lipid composition that is not adequate to maintain the membrane integrity at the higher temperatures [44]. At prolonged exposures and higher temperatures this phenomenon is further facilitated by reduction

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: and loss of membrane appression as shown by the trend in our TEM pictures (Fig. 2). Our findings are in excellent agreement with [30,31] in the sense that temperature stress induces loss of membrane integrity, including loss of membrane appression for dinoflagellate strains that are sensitive to temperature-induced bleaching.

This "super-quenching" mechanism ( Fig. 6), where excess excitation energy is directed towards PSI, forms the basis of the temperature-induced photosynthetic activity breakdown in both intact corals and isolated dinoflagellate cells. The mechanism potentially allows recovery of the photosynthetic apparatus from the heat-induced state for short and mild exposures to elevated temperatures. Under long-term heat stress permanent damage to the cells may be induced. For strains that are not temperature sensitive, no such heat-induced loss of membrane integrity was observed [30] or the loss of photosynthetic activity was shifted to higher temperatures [43,45]. (P 700 + is a highly efficient quenching center for excitation energy [41,42]. In low light, when PSI is not oxidized, the spillover mechanism can balance the excitation energy distribution between PSII and PSI.

div.head: Breakdown of lateral segregation and linear electron flow
div.p: Clearly, the reorganization capacity of the thylakoid membranes in Symbiodinium Clade C cells permits significant flexibility of the energy distribution between PSII and PSI. If performed in a controlled manner it can be a powerful regulation mechanism. However, an excessive breakdown of membrane structureas seems to occur under heat stress conditionstriggers complete and uncontrolled spillover, which efficiently shuts down linear electron flow through PSII (without

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: actual PSII damage initially) and ultimately leads to a catastrophic breakdown of photosynthetic activity.

It has been found earlier that bleaching conditions dramatically reduce the efficiency of PSII and of CO 2 fixation [5,6,46]. Previously this was attributed primarily to a damage of PSII units (e.g. photoinhibition etc. [23,47]); however, the actual occurrence of photoinhibition has been questioned [30]. Our results can explain all these previous data in terms of the functional loss of PSII activity, without actually requiring an initial damage of PSII units. The total loss of PSII/PSI segregation and the shift of part of the PSII peripheral antennae (15-20%) to PSI under heat stress switches the PSA into the "super-quenching" state, where less than 5% of all the photons absorbed by the PSII antenna cause electron transfer, while more than 95% are converted into heat. Therefore, all the kinetic parameters of the PSII units in this state indicate an intact electron transfer capability. Yet, the strong spillover has the same effect of strongly reducing the PSII yield, measured as F v /F m , just as a real damage of PSII centers would do. This explains why the two entirely different mechanisms cannot be distinguished in the conventional steady-state fluorescence measurements. Overall, under combined heat and light stress conditions, the linear electron flow in the entire PSA breaks downs, along with all the ensuing negative consequences for adenosine-5'-triphosphate synthesis and carbon fixation that have been reported as characteristics of the coral symbionts under bleaching conditions [5,6,16].

Notwithstanding the fact that the conclusions made here are based on cultured Symbiodinium cells they can still provide an important insight into the potential mechanism existing during natural coral bleaching. The loss of photosynthetic function in the Symbiodinium cells under prolonged thermal stress is a major factor that could eventually cause expulsion or death of the algal symbiont [48], resulting in a bleached coral, but there is likely to be a delicate balance between this condition and over-reduction of PSI leading to the production of ROS [9].
Ironically, modest spillover actually does protect the most vulnerable component of the PSA -PSIIin a similar manner as the normal light-induced NPQ of other organisms [19,28].

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Our results provide a molecular basis for understanding the mechanisms of the heat-induced loss of thylakoid integrity and the ensuing loss of photosynthetic function due to the total breakdown of linear electron flow. This insight now enables us to examine and correlate differences (in cultures and in hospite) in bleaching between the various Symbiodinium clades and their photoprotective mechanisms suggested by some recent results in the literature (cf. [39,[49][50][51]).

As bleaching varies between species and habitats, this new understanding is essential for estimating expected climate change effects on coral reefs [7]. Future studies need to integrate this "super-quenching" state into our understanding of how symbiotic Symbiodinium of tropical coral reefs will respond to a changing climate [16,49].

figure.figDesc: Symbiodinium cultures used in the experiments were from the strain CS-156 (corresponding to clade C, originating from the Hawaiian scleractinian coral Montipora verrucosa; obtained from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO), Hobart, Australia). The algae were grown in f/2 medium [21] at 24 °C under 40 mol photons m -2 s -1 on a 12:12 h light:dark cycle. In preparation for the picosecond time-resolved fluorescence measurements, algae were concentrated using a centrifuge at 1000 g for 10 min; the supernatant was discarded and algae were resuspended in 1 L of fresh f/2 medium to a cell concentration of ~10000-15000 cells/ml. During the experiments, the algae were continuously stirred to keep them in a homogenous suspension and monitored for aggregation on the reservoir walls. To prevent clumping of the algae culture, which created a problem with the flow-through cuvette, the sample reservoirs were treated for short periods of time in an ultrasound bath at 80 W (Sonorex Digitec DT 100/H, Bandelin, Germany) at random intervals during the experimental runs. The monitoring of the effective quantum yield of PSII (ΔF/F m ) by a Water Pulse-Amplitude Modulated (water-PAM)

figure.head: Fig. 1 )
figure.figDesc: : 1) control condition (F C )unquenched cells with closed (Q A -) PSII reaction centers (RCs) at growth temperature of 24°C (immediately before the measurement the culture was treated with 10 µM DCMU and 10 µmol photons m -2 s -1 of illumination was applied to the sample reservoir for closing PSII reaction centers during the measurement); 2) high light stress (F HL )quenched high light-adapted cells during both incubation and measurement periods (600 µmol photons m -2 s -1 illumination on the sample reservoir at 24°C); 3) elevated temperature stress (F HT )unquenched cells at high temperature (31°C and 10 µmol photons m -2 s -1 illumination) during the incubation period, which were converted to quenched light-adapted cells with closed PSII RCs for the measurement periods (31°C and 600 µmol photons m -2 s -1 illumination on the sample reservoir), and 4) quenched light-adapted cells (F B ) (31°C and 600 µmol photons m -2 s -1 illumination on the sample reservoir) during both the incubation and the measurement periods and closed PSII RCs during measurement period; equivalent to coral bleaching conditions.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Schematic representation of the four different conditions applied to the Symbiodinium cells (see text for details). The sun symbol indicates high light stress, while the red wavy arrows indicate elevated temperature.

figure.head: Fig. 2 shows
figure.figDesc: TEM images of thin-sectioned cells. The typical banded pattern of thylakoid membranes in chloroplasts of dinoflagellates is clearly visibleFig. 2A-C, F-G). As is typical, in this Symbiodinium strain the bands are composed of three thylakoids each, i.e. six membranes surround three lumenal spaces, whereby the stromal facing membranes of the inner thylakoids are closely attached. The bands and the distances between membranes have a very regular and typical appearance in the dark-adapted at 24°C control cells(Fig. 2 A, D).

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Transmission electron micrographs of control Synbiodinium cells (24°C and dark adapted, A and E), cells incubated at 31°C and illuminated with 600 μmol photons/m 2 •s for 8h (B and F), cells incubated at 33°C and 60 μmol photons/m2•s for 12 h (C and G) and cells kept at 33°C and 240 μmol photons/m 2 •s for 12 h (D) at low (x40000, A-D) and high (x110000, E-G) magnification. Scale bars represent 200 nm in A-D and 100 nm in E-G. Mean values and standard deviations (n = 30) of the overall width of the thylakoid bands are shown in H. *** symbolizes p < 0.001 in a non-paired t-test, n.s. = not significant.When cells were incubated at higher temperatures (31°C) in the dark, no changes occurred (data not shown). If additionally illuminated with strong light (600 μmol photons/m 2 •s) for 8h, again no significant differences were visible(Fig. 2B/F/H). The thylakoid bands were still arranged in a regular pattern and distances between membranes changed very little compared to the low temperature, dark-adapted controls. When using still higher temperature (33°C) for longer timesA C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T(12h), structural changes became visible. Under this regime, even illumination with only 60 μmol photons/m 2 •s for 12h was enough to change the thylakoid membrane arrangement:

figure.head: Fig. 2H ,
figure.label: 2H
figure.figDesc: incubation at 33°C and 60 μmol photons/m 2 •s leads to a significant increase in width, whereas for thylakoids incubated at 31° under very high light as shown in Fig. 2B/F the trend to increase is not significant. At higher light intensities (240 μmol photons/m 2 •s) and high temperature (33°C) for 12 h, the whole thylakoid structure disintegrated (Fig. 2 D) [30, 31]. 3.2. Time-resolved Chl fluorescence Time-resolved Chl fluorescence experiments with picosecond time resolution were carried out on Symbiodinium cells (strain CS-156, clade C, see Materials and methods for growth conditions, preparation of the samples, and details on the experimental set-up and the measurement conditions) to reveal the photoprotective mechanisms and adaptations induced in the PSA of the algae cells under light and temperature stress conditions. The cells were exposed to four different experimental treatments (Fig. 1): i) control condition (F C )unquenched cells; ii) high light stress(600 μmol photons m -2 s -1 ) (F HL ); iii) elevated temperature stress at 32°C (F HT ); and, iv) combined temperature and high light stress, equivalent to coral bleaching conditions (F B ). To compare these conditions at an equal level, all measurements were carried out with the PSII reaction centers (RCs) in a closed (Q A -) state (see Materials and methods)[28].

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Kinetic models used for describing the primary reactions in the PSA of Symbiodinium cells under the different treatments. A) kinetic scheme describing PSII that is not involved in spillover with PSI; B) kinetic compartment describing peripheral antenna complexes that are associated neither with PSII nor with PSI; C) kinetic schemes describing PSI and PSII involved in spillover. Model compartments: i) PSII/RC compartmenta combined antenna-RC compartment representing the PSII complexes together with their peripheral antenna, this compartment could either be involved in spillover with PSI or not; ii) PSI/RC compartmenta combined antenna-RC compartment accounting for PSI and its peripheral antenna; iii) radical pair (RP) compartmentsaccounting for the electron transfer reaction in each of the photosystems.

for the different compartments are proportional to the relative absorption cross-sections of the associated pigment complexes at the excitation wavelength and thus provided good estimates of the relative antenna sizes, i.e. the relative amounts of light captured directly by the various PSUs.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: DAS and SAES resulting from the kinetic modeling of the time-resolved fluorescence data from Symbiodinium cells under the following treatments: A, D) F C condition; B, E) F HL condition; C, F) F B condition. (see SI,

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Molecular model for thylakoid architecture and its reorganization induced under elevated thermal stress in Symbiodinium. A) at optimal growth temperature conditions -two PSII pools: one that is involved in excitation spillover with PSI and another that is not; B) at elevated temperatures (with or without high light) -homogeneous PSII -PSI distribution in the thylakoid membrane, causing the formation of the "super-quenching" centers (as indicated by the highlighted box in B; cf.Fig. 6for details) and the increase in the effective antenna size of PSI.

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Model of the arrangement of a "super-quenched" PSII/PSI complex. The straight arrows indicate the major energy transfer (spillover) processes. Quenching (indicated by the wavy arrow) occurs in the PSI complex by P 700 +

(controls grown at 24°C and dark adapted, and stressed cells incubated at 31°C and 600 μmol photons/m 2 •s for 8 h) were used. In addition, cells incubated at 33°C and 60 μmol photons/m 2 •s or 240 μmol photons/m 2 •s for 12 hours were examined as well. Cells were harvested by centrifugation (15 min at 7,000 g) and fixed in 0.08 M cacodylate buffer containing 4% glutaraldehyde and 8.6% sucrose at 4°C for at least 2h. Pellets were washed twice in the same buffer without glutaraldehyde and then fixed further in 2% OsO 4 for 3 h. After dehydration in an ascending ethanol series (30-100%), samples were embedded in Araldite, sectioned with an ultramicrotome (50 nm thickness), stained with uranyl acetate and lead acetate for 8 min, and

figure.head: Table 1 .
figure.figDesc: Relative excitation vectors (excitation probability for the different compartments), spillover and NPQ rates, and average lifetimes for each of the four treatments described in Section 3.2.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We are grateful to the staff of the Max-Planck Institute in Mülheim/Ruhr for support with the culturing of the organism and the spectroscopic experiments. Claudia Büchel thanks Marion Basoglu for the preparing the samples and recording the TEM images. ARH and CB acknowledge the EU Marie Curie Training and Research Network "Harvest". PR acknowledges the support by the Australian Research Council.

The authors see no conflicts of interest in this work.
